pull.title: release: require macOS 10.10+
pull.body:
Closes #13362

d99abfddb0c8f2111340a6127e77cc686e0043d8
This workaround should no longer be required, as it should have only been in use when compiled with the 10.7 SDK, which we haven't been building with for a while now.

5bc5ae30982a0f0f6a9804b05d99434af770c724
The bugreport linked with this code is for an unrelated? issue, however from what I can tell the correct QTBUG is this one https://bugreports.qt.io/browse/QTBUG-20880. Reading though the discussion there, it seems that the way progress bars are animated changed in macOS 10.10. 
Qt was patched [here (5.5+)](https://codereview.qt-project.org/#/c/112379/):
> Disable progress bar animations on 10.10 Yosemite and higher - the native style does not animate them any more. Keep the indeterminate progress bar animation.

Given all of that, I don't think this is worth keeping around, as it would seem to only be useful in the case that a macOS user is compiling with a Qt < 5.5. That should be pretty unlikely, as we don't support downloaded Qt binaries, and brew currently provides [5.11.1](https://github.com/Homebrew/homebrew-core/blob/571b46213c70ca1573da6d0425b0bd6df34961ee/Formula/qt.rb).

issue.title: OSX -> macOS
issue.body: Replaced OSX with macOS in places I thought were appropriate and added a couple of small unification changes.

events.body:
<!--e57a25ab6845829454e8d69fc972939a-->Note to reviewers: This pull request conflicts with the following ones:

* #13755 ([WIP] Full unicode support on Windows by ken2812221)
* #13426 ([bugfix] Add u8path and u8string to fix encoding issue for Windows by ken2812221)

If you consider this pull request important, please also help to review the conflicting pull requests. Ideally, start with the one that should be merged first.

issue.title: [bugfix] Fix encoding issue for Windows
issue.body:
Fix #13103 
Fix #13754

From https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/13107#issuecomment-385141831, @laanwj suggested that we should keep our internal strings to be always utf-8 encoded.

This PR adds two C++17 compatible macros: `u8string` and `u8path`. The reason that I use macros is that developers might not want to pass second parameter `utf8` everytime when they call `string` or create `path` objects.

I tried to find all `string` methods and convert them to `u8string` except for external api calls. Also tried to convert explicit or implicit `path` to `u8path`. Tell me if you find something that I missed.

Required: bitcoin-core/leveldb#18

See #13787 for travis run result


Caution: The user must change their config file to be utf-8 encoded if the file contains any non-ascii characters in it. Before 0.18, they are read as ansi-encoded characters on Windows.
--

events.body:
Concept ACK.
Changes look good.
Does someone has a 10.10 build environment? I guess would be great to test on 10.9 (failcase-test) and on 10.10.
Appears to time out, but builds on my travis when merged with #13634

issue.title: lint: Run the CI lint stage on mac
issue.body: This helps ensure ongoing compatibility with macOS-distributed version of GNU bash.

events.body: Rebased on master. Removed the [wip] tag. There were a couple todos left, but they aren't critical for 0.17.0, and can be done for 0.18.0 alongside PRs like #13561.
Should the darwin11 also be updated when `make download-osx` in depends?

tACK 5eb615c, modulo #13752 and the `depends/Makefile` darwin11 reference @MarcoFalke pointed out.

I also built depends, ran functional test with that, then ran regular tests without depends (see #13750). I switched GUI to Mandarin, looks nice. I didn't check if the progress bar uses CPU when disconnected.

issue.title: RFC: Set minimum required macOS version to 10.10
issue.body:
After some discussion with @jonasschnelli, I've put together a few notes about increasing our minimum supported version of macOS.

Our current minimum is [10.8](https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/blob/master/depends/hosts/darwin.mk#L1).
We're using the 10.11 [SDK](https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/blob/master/depends/hosts/darwin.mk#L2).

There's currently #12971 open to upgrade Qt in depends to 5.9.x (up from 5.7.1). Starting with Qt 5.9.x the minimum supported version of macOS is [10.10](https://wiki.qt.io/Qt_5.9_Tools_and_Versions#osx_10.10_x86_64).

Targeting 10.10+ should allow us to remove some macOS specific backwards compatibility code as well:
* Font substitution in [guiutil.cpp](https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/blob/master/src/qt/guiutil.cpp#L420).
* Weak linking in [macnotificationhandler.mm](https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/blob/master/src/qt/macnotificationhandler.mm#L36). Note this could probably be dropped already, due to 10.8+.

@theuni be good to get your thoughts re Clang, cctools, macOS SDK etc.

Tagged with a 0.17.0 milestone, as if we plan to upgrade Qt in depends, this will need addressing somehow.

events.body:
@fanquake what was the rationale for using `MAC_OSX`? I can't find any documentation about it.

This (fairly old) blog post recommends a different strategy: http://nadeausoftware.com/articles/2012/01/c_c_tip_how_use_compiler_predefined_macros_detect_operating_system#OSXiOSandDarwin

issue.title: Modernise macOS cross-compilation toolchain
issue.body:
Cherry-picked from the following upstream PRs:

- bitcoin/bitcoin#13617
  - Excluding the QT GUI changes.
- bitcoin/bitcoin#17550
- bitcoin/bitcoin#16392
  - Excluding the QT GUI changes.
- bitcoin/bitcoin#18589
- bitcoin/bitcoin#19240
- bitcoin/bitcoin#19407
- bitcoin/bitcoin#17919
  - Only the ancillary changes, not the `FORCE_USE_SYSTEM_CLANG` change.
- bitcoin/bitcoin#19530

After these changes, macOS versions earlier than 10.12 are no longer supported.

To cross-compile for macOS:
- Follow the instructions in `contrib/macdeploy/README.md` to generate
  `Xcode-11.3.1-11C505-extracted-SDK-with-libcxx-headers.tar.gz`
  (requires an Apple Developer Account)
- Extract it into `depends/SDKs` (creating that folder first if it does not exist)
- `HOST=x86_64-apple-darwin16 ./zcutil/build.sh`

labels.name: C-upstream-port
labels.description: Category: Changes that are ported from the Bitcoin Core codebase.

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -719,8 +719,8 @@ fs::path GetDefaultDataDir()
         pathRet = fs::path("/");
     else
         pathRet = fs::path(pszHome);
-#ifdef MAC_OSX
-    // Mac
+#ifdef __APPLE__
comments.body: Do we for sure mean "Apple" in all of these changes and not just "macOS"? This would affect iOS as well, which seems likely incorrect here. I suspect that we want to keep using MAC_OSX (which we define ourselves) so that we can differentiate later if needed.

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -22,7 +22,7 @@ Common `host-platform-triplets` for cross compilation are:
 
 - `i686-w64-mingw32` for Win32
 - `x86_64-w64-mingw32` for Win64
-- `x86_64-apple-darwin11` for macOS
+- `x86_64-apple-darwin14` for macOS

@@ -22,7 +22,7 @@ Common `host-platform-triplets` for cross compilation are:
 
 - `i686-w64-mingw32` for Win32
 - `x86_64-w64-mingw32` for Win64
-- `x86_64-apple-darwin11` for macOS
+- `x86_64-apple-darwin14` for macOS
comments.body:
@theuni  In the readme it's cosmetic, darwin11 refers to OS X 10.7, darwin14 should be 10.10. 
However good catch, as we should also be changing this in [travis.yml](https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/blob/master/.travis.yml#L43) and [gitian-osx.yml](https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/blob/master/contrib/gitian-descriptors/gitian-osx.yml#L37) ?

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -22,7 +22,7 @@ Common `host-platform-triplets` for cross compilation are:
 
 - `i686-w64-mingw32` for Win32
 - `x86_64-w64-mingw32` for Win64
-- `x86_64-apple-darwin11` for macOS
+- `x86_64-apple-darwin14` for macOS
comments.body: Huh, how does this even compile on travis/gitian, given that support for 10.7 has been removed?

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -22,7 +22,7 @@ Common `host-platform-triplets` for cross compilation are:
 
 - `i686-w64-mingw32` for Win32
 - `x86_64-w64-mingw32` for Win64
-- `x86_64-apple-darwin11` for macOS
+- `x86_64-apple-darwin14` for macOS
comments.body: I've never seen a case where this changes anything in practice. As a test, I just had a look at gcc's configure.ac though, and it at least checks for >=10 in a few places. So I guess we should keep these in sync to be on the safe side.
Has someone verified that this BUG no longer appears on OSX 10.10+?

The new URL for the bug appears to be https://bugreports.qt.io/browse/QTBUG-15631 but that bug seems unrelated to the comment.
@kallewoof I mentioned in the PR description, from what I can tell the correct link is https://bugreports.qt.io/browse/QTBUG-20880
